Question_1.Context: In magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), the use of high-dielectric materials can affect the spatial distribution of electromagnetic fields.
Question_1.Question: What is the primary purpose of using high-dielectric materials in MRI?
Question_1.B: To increase the strength of the transmit and receive magnetic fields in low sensitivity areas
Question_1.C: To reduce the overall scan time
Question_1.Source: The high-dielectric pad is composed of high-permittivity materials (e.g., barium titanate [BaTiO3] and calcium titanate [CaTiO3]), which are effective in altering the spatial distribution of electromagnetic fields and enlarging the shortened wavelength of B1 for high-field MRI applications of the brain or body.

Question_2.Context: Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) is a type of MRI that can be used to measure the diffusion of water molecules in tissue, which can reveal microstructural details about the brain.
Question_2.Question: What aspect of neuronal structure is primarily indicated by quantitative anisotropy (QA) in DTI?
Question_2.Source: Among DTI values, QA was used. Neuroimaging studies commonly use fractional anisotropy (FA) values rather than QA values in DTI study, however there are differences between them. FA is defined for each voxel and associated with axonal integrity. On the other hand, QA is defined for each fiber orientation and associated with axonal density.

Question_3.Context: In MRI, the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) is an important metric that indicates the quality of the image; higher SNR usually means a clearer image.
Question_3.Question: What is the relationship between ultra-high field MRI and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR)?
Question_3.A: Ultra-high field MRI decreases SNR compared to lower-field MRI
Question_3.B: Ultra-high field MRI has no effect on SNR
Question_3.C: Ultra-high field MRI increases SNR compared to lower-field MRI
Question_3.D: Ultra-high field MRI and SNR are unrelated
Question_3.Source: Theoretically, ultra-high field magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) (≥ 7 T) has a higher signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), which leads to higher spatiotemporal resolution and enhanced tissue contrast, compared with lower-field MRI (≤ 3 T).

Question_4.Context: In MRI, T1-weighted images (T1w) are one of the basic pulse sequences used to provide specific diagnostic information.
Question_4.Question: What is the significance of T1-weighted images (T1w) in MRI?
Question_4.A: They are used to measure the temperature of the body
Question_4.B: They are used to detect the movement of the MRI machine
Question_4.C: They are used to enhance the contrast in images of the brain's anatomy
Question_4.D: They are used to measure the speed of blood flow
Question_4.Source: Three-dimensional (3D) anatomical brain scans were acquired using magnetization prepared rapid acquisition gradient echo (MP-RAGE) sequence-induced T1w images with the following settings: repetition time (TR) = 4500 ms, echo time (TE) = 1.48 ms, flip angle (FA) = 6°, slice thickness = 0.8 mm, in-plane resolution = 0.8 × 0.8 mm2, matrix size = 304 × 304, number of slices = 192, total scan time = 8 min 8 s.

Question_5.Context: In MRI, passive shimming is a technique used to improve image quality by compensating for inhomogeneities in the magnetic field.
Question_5.Question: What is the role of passive shimming in MRI?
Question_5.A: To actively adjust the magnetic field using electronic components
Question_5.B: To decrease the resolution of the images
Question_5.C: To increase the speed of image acquisition
Question_5.D: To compensate for magnetic field inhomogeneities and improve image quality
Question_5.Source: To compensate for B1 interference with the human body, RF shimming is commonly used; it is a technique that uses a transmit array (active shimming) and high-dielectric material (passive shimming).

Question_6.Context: In neuroimaging, the corticospinal tract (CST) is an important neural pathway that connects the brain to the spinal cord and is involved in motor control.
Question_6.Question: What is the significance of the corticospinal tract (CST) in neuroimaging studies?
Question_6.A: It is associated with visual processing
Question_6.B: It is related to memory function
Question_6.C: It is involved in motor control
Question_6.D: It is important for auditory signal processing
Question_6.Source: Compared to the images acquired without high-dielectric pad, those acquired with high-dielectric pad showed a significantly higher quantitative anisotropy (QA) signal in the corticospinal tract (CST), frontopontine tract (FPT), splenium of the corpus callosum (SCC), fornix (FX), inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus (IFOF), cerebellum (CB), middle cerebellar peduncle (MCP), and body of the corpus callosum (BCC) (p < 0.003).

Question_7.Context: In MRI, the specific absorption rate (SAR) is a measure of the rate at which energy is absorbed by the body when exposed to a radiofrequency (RF) electromagnetic field.
Question_7.Question: What does the specific absorption rate (SAR) indicate in the context of MRI?
Question_7.A: The amount of contrast agent used
Question_7.B: The rate of energy absorbed by the body from the RF field
Question_7.C: The speed of the MRI scanning process
Question_7.D: The strength of the magnetic field
Question_7.Source: However, ultra-high field imaging faces technical challenges due to radiofrequency (RF) inhomogeneity, increased tissue heating, and reduced wavelength of the RF field (B1).

Question_8.Context: In MRI, echo planar imaging (EPI) is a fast imaging technique that forms the basis for most functional MRI.
Question_8.Question: What is one of the challenges associated with echo planar imaging (EPI) in MRI?
Question_8.A: It requires a very long scan time
Question_8.B: It is associated with signal loss and imaging blurring due to B1 field inhomogeneity
Question_8.C: It cannot be used with high-field MRI systems
Question_8.D: It produces images with very high tissue heating
Question_8.Source: One of the challenges of EPI are artifacts which associated with signal loss and imaging blurring leading to non-diagnostic quality derived from B1 field inhomogeneity.

Question_9.Context: In MRI, the flip angle (FA) is a parameter that can be adjusted during the scan to influence the contrast and signal intensity of the images.
Question_9.Question: What is the role of the flip angle (FA) in MRI?
Question_9.A: To determine the duration of the MRI scan
Question_9.B: To adjust the contrast and signal intensity of the images
Question_9.C: To measure the temperature inside the MRI scanner
Question_9.D: To control the speed of the rotating magnetic field
Question_9.Source: Three-dimensional (3D) anatomical brain scans were acquired using magnetization prepared rapid acquisition gradient echo (MP-RAGE) sequence-induced T1w images with the following settings: repetition time (TR) = 4500 ms, echo time (TE) = 1.48 ms, flip angle (FA) = 6°, slice thickness = 0.8 mm, in-plane resolution = 0.8 × 0.8 mm2, matrix size = 304 × 304, number of slices = 192, total scan time = 8 min 8 s.

Question_10.Context: Barium titanate (BaTiO3) is a high-permittivity material used in high-dielectric pads for MRI.
Question_10.Question: What is the role of barium titanate (BaTiO3) in high-dielectric pads for MRI?
Question_10.A: To decrease the permittivity of the pad
Question_10.B: To reduce the signal intensity of the images
Question_10.C: To increase the permittivity of the pad and alter electromagnetic field distribution
Question_10.D: To act as a contrast agent for imaging
Question_10.Source: The high-dielectric pad is composed of high-permittivity materials (e.g., barium titanate [BaTiO3] and calcium titanate [CaTiO3]), which are effective in altering the spatial distribution of electromagnetic fields and enlarging the shortened wavelength of B1 for high-field MRI applications of the brain or body.
